_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Crude Petroleum and Natural Gas Extraction

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES

Chesapeake Energy Marketing, Inc. owns and operates a natural gas processing site, the Daube Ranch Compressor Station, in Johnston County, Oklahoma. The station is designed to process natural gas, during which liquid products are recovered from natural gas. Both petroleum condensates and natural gas liquids are recovered from the inlet pipeline gas in this process for offsite sales.

The Daube Ranch Compressor Station has a long-standing commitment to workers and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by our efforts in accident prevention, such as training personnel, quality assurance, and considering safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of our process. Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However if a release does occur, facility trained personnel will evaluate the situation, take actions within the capabilities of the facility, and notify the necessary outside agencies.

DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Daube Ranch Compressor Station is located near Gene Autry, Oklahoma and operates a variety of processes to produce the following petroleum products:

1. Y grade mixture from natural gas

OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS RESULTS

The worst-case scenario (WCS) associated with a release of flammable substances at Daube Ranch Compressor Station is a vapor cloud explosion involving 293,548 pounds (60,000 gallons) of a flammable mixture contained in the product tank. Using the EPA OCA Guidance Equations, the entire inventory is assumed to release and ignite, resulting in a vapor cloud explosion that reaches the 1 psi overpressure point at 0.54 miles. The WCS will affect two public receptors. A consideration of the 0.54 mile radius has been incorporated into our notification and emergency response planning. 

Chesapeake's management is committed to the following:
-Preventing accidents;
-Training

our employees in correct response procedures in the event of an accident;
-Participating in community emergency preparedness;
-Addressing any citizen concerns by fully explaining potential hazards associated with Chesapeake operations and all steps being taken to prevent and mitigate accidents; and
-Being a good corporate citizen of Johnston County.

With these objectives in mind, this Risk Management Plan has been developed to provide information about our management of the risks associated with the natural gas treatment and liquids recovery process. Most importantly, we stress our commitment to ensuring a safe operation for our employees, our visitors, and our community. 

The alternative release scenario (ARS) for the flammable substances at Daube Ranch Compressor Station is a vapor cloud explosion resulting from the release of the flammable mixture from a 2? hole at the bottom of the Product Tank (9,900 lb/min).  The release is expected to be isolated by operations personnel within 15 minutes or by automated station shutdown system to shutdown all engines, station utilities and actuated valves to their fail-safe position, diverting all incoming gas to the flare. The resulting vapor cloud explosion reaches the 1 psi overpressure point at 0.43 miles.

GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

Employee Participation

Chesapeake encourages employees to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention as follows:
1. Updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information
2. Performing necessary calculations for RMP
3. Maintaining good engineering practices
4. Participating as a member of a process hazard analysis (PHA) team
Employees have access to all information pertaining to the accident prevention program.

Process Safety Information

Chesapeake keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes. These technical documents address the following:
1. Chemical properties

and associated hazards
2. Necessary Block Flow Diagrams of the process
3. Maximum intended inventories
4. Upper and Lower limits of process fixed and rotating equipment
5. Equipment design basis and configuration information
6. Identification of all necessary Regulatory equipment design documents
7. Sufficient information to assure good engineering practices

Chemical ?specific information, including hazard and emergency response/exposure considerations, is provided in material safety data sheet (MSDS). For specific process areas, the facility has documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters such as temperatures, level and composition in the operators? procedures manual. The facility maintains the process within these limits by using process controls and monitoring instruments, trained personnel and protective instrument systems such as automated shutdown systems.

The facility also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of the process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressures, temperature and electrical ratings. This information, in combination with procedures and equipment operating history, provides a basis for inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to safety features in the process are not compromised.

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

Chesapeake has a comprehensive program to identify and control hazards associated with the RMP covered process. This program systematically examines for potential hazards and puts controls in place to manage hazards. Process Hazard Analysis is conducted with a team of Chesapeake employees who have operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise. The team identifies, evaluates and makes recommendations to management of potential hazards identified. The team?s findings are forward to Chesapeake?s Management for resolution. The approve

d mitigation options in response to the PHA team?s findings are tracked until they are completed. The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained.

The facility periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results. These periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years and will be conducted at this frequency until the process is no longer operating. The results and findings from these updates are documented and retained.

Operating Procedures

Chesapeake maintains written Operating Procedures of the covered process that address primary operations mandated by OSHA, EPA, Good Engineering Practice and manufacturers. These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators. Procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as current accurate by management. The procedures are maintained current and accurate revising them as necessary.
Covered Process Operating procedures are readily available to operators in the process unit and for other personnel to use as necessary to safely perform their job task and maintain the covered process unit operating within its safe limits.

Training

Chesapeake has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating the covered process. New employees receive basic training in process operations if they are not already familiar with such operations. After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks. A performance review and written test specific to the facility operations is administered and must be successfully completed during this training period. After the operator demonstrates adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they are allowed to work independently. In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to ensure that

their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level. This refresher training is conducted at least every 3 years, or more frequently upon request. All training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify and demonstrate skills.

Mechanical Integrity

Chesapeake has established practices and procedures for the safe operation of fixed, rotating and emergency shutdown equipment. The basic aspects of the program include, but are not limited to, the following:

1. Conducting training
2. Developing written procedures
3. Performing inspections and tests
4. Correcting identified deficiencies
5. Applying quality assurance measures

In combination, these activities form a system to maintain the mechanical integrity of the process.

Maintenance personnel receive training on:
1. Overview of the process
2. Safety and Health hazards
3. Applicable maintenance procedures
4. Emergency response plan
5. Applicable safe work practices to help ensure that they can perform their jobs in a safe manner.

Written procedures provide that work is performed in a consistent manner and serve as a basis for training. Inspections and tests are performed to help verify that equipment function as intended and that equipment is within acceptable limits. If a deficiency is identified and the situation presents an immediate safety concern, the deficiency is corrected before placing the equipment back into service. 

Incident Investigation

Chesapeake promptly investigates all incidents related to a covered process that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in a fire/explosion, property damage, environmental loss or personal injury. The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective action to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent future occurrences and forwards these results to facility management for resolution. Corrective a

ctions taken in response to the investigation team?s findings and recommendations are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented and investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years.

Compliance Audits

At least every 3 years a Compliance Audit addressing all OSHA, EPA, RMP and Good Engineering Practices are conducted by employees and management of Daube Ranch Compressor Station. This audit team develops findings that are forwarded to facility management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team?s findings are tracked until they are completed. Final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Daube Ranch Compressor Station has had no RMP-regulated substance release during the past five years.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION

Daube Ranch Compressor Station is a Non-Responding Facility as per 48 CFR 68.90(b). The station maintains a written emergency action plan, which is in place to help protect employees and public safety as well as the environment. The plan identifies steps to be taken in case of an accidental release including: proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs.

Employees receive training in the procedures to be followed by employees who remain to operate critical station operations before they evacuate. Chesapeake has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate emergency response organizations (Fire Department, Police and Sheriff?s Office). This interface provides the means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident. In addition, Chesapeake conducts periodic emergency drills and annual refresher training for station personnel.
